name: Lithuania
takeaway: Since early 2021, Lithuania has embarked on a major review of its relationship with China, including coinciding outreach toward Taiwan, resulting in an often unprecedented and multi-dimensional Chinese pressure campaign that partly continued at the time of data collection.

Therefore, China's influence in Lithuania has decreased, as diplomatic relations remain downgraded to the level of chargé d'affaires while its most damaging economic coercion measures against the country were quietly suspended.

In this context, Chinese influence appears to be somewhat more apparent and sustainable in areas below the high politics of international relations and security, such as academia, domestic politics, and society.
description-1: In 2023, Lithuania had a GDP per capita of US$27,103 and a total population of 2.84 million people.
description-2: Lithuania established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1991. Lithuania was ranked 13th in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 89/100.

Media.evidence: Several of Lithuanian print and digital media outlets are known to have been publishing op-eds and articles originating at the local Chinese embassy, strongly suggesting payment for such services. However, the number of such instances, rare to begin with, seems to have substantially reduced since the beginning of the bilateral relationship crisis in 2021. Therefore, this Indicator deserves a "Few" and "Insignificant" rating.

Foreign Policy.evidence: In the Seimas (Lithuanian parliament), there is a Group for Inter-Parliamentary Relations with the People's Republic of China. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Yes" response.

Foreign Policy.evidence: In the context of the ongoing Sino-Lithuanian relationship crisis, the country's last ambassador, Diana Mickevičienė, had to endure a three-week compulsory quarantine when the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced the mutual withdrawal of ambassadors on the same day she landed in Beijing after a short trip back to Lithuania in late August 2021. The perception in Vilnius was that this action was premeditated to make the ambassador a temporary de facto hostage before she could return to her country. Less than three months later, China unilaterally downgraded its official relationship with Lithuania to the level of chargé d’affaires and asked the staff of the Lithuanian embassy in Beijing to hand in their accreditation cards by mid-December. Concerned about the implications for their diplomatic immunity, all of the embassy’s Lithuanian employees, along with their family members, left China on December 15 in what international media described as an “evacuation.” However, none of the Lithuanian diplomats have de jure been detained in China or denied exit for political reasons. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "No" response.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Lithuania positively supported the July 2016 South China Sea arbitration ruling issued by the UNCLOS Arbitral Tribunal. Its Indo-Pacific Strategy, issued in mid-2023, specifically mentioned China's military activity in the South China Sea as aggravating the security situation in the Indo-Pacific region. Lithuania's social media communication on the matter has also been plainly critical. Therefore, the index country has rejected the PRC’s territorial claim, and the indicator warrants a 0 score.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Lithuania has clearly and consistently expressed its criticism of China regarding this matter on both domestic and international levels. Therefore, the index country has denounced the PRC’s treatment of its Uyghur population, and the indicator warrants a 0 score.

Academia.evidence: In 2013, the Huawei Computer Network Academy, focused on offering the Huawei Certified Datacom Associate certification, officially opened at the country's oldest and largest university. Except for the website, there is no public evidence that the program is actually functioning at the time of this writing. The same seems to be the case for the three Lithuanian universities—Vilnius University, Vilnius Gediminas Technical University, and Kaunas University of Technology—that signed cooperation agreements with Huawei under the "Seeds for the Future" program back in 2016. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Few" and "Insignificant" rating.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: There is one Confucius Institute at Vilnius University (since 2010) and two Confucius Classrooms in Vilnius and Kaunas, the country's two largest cities. There is no evidence of any adverse impact of the Confucius Institute on Vilnius University or the country at large. A telling test of Chinese influence over the university occurred when its authorities organized a widely-attended public lecture by the visiting Dalai Lama in mid-2018. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Few" and "Insignificant" rating.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: Chinese language is taught at two engineering lyceums with Confucius Classrooms. However, there are no plans to include its teaching on a national basis. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "No" response.

Domestic Politics.evidence: At least eight Lithuanian municipalities had documented sister-city ties with Chinese counterparts before the pandemic. However, these have not led to any tangible manifestations of note. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "More than a few" and "Insignificant" rating.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Although the Association of Local Authorities in Lithuania has an international cooperation agreement with the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, a United Front entity, no trips to China seem to have taken place in 2022 and 2023, unlike the period before the pandemic.

Domestic Politics.evidence: In response to Lithuania's 2021 review of its relationship with China, Beijing embarked on a multi-dimensional pressure campaign against the country. This included informational attacks against Lithuania, its current government, and its representatives. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "More than a few" and "Significant" rating.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: In early January 2022, while commenting on the Sino-Lithuanian bilateral relationship crisis, Ramūnas Karbauskis, a wealthy businessman and the head of the main political party that formed Lithuania’s previous governing coalition (2016–2020), implied that the country's review of its relations with China followed US orders, mirroring one of the most important Chinese talking points on the matter. This seems to have been an important but isolated incident, however. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Few" and "Significant" rating.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Economy.evidence: Since 2013, one of Lithuania's largest electric facility engineering companies, Energy Network Institute, has been majority-owned by North China Power Engineering. Although it is not a piece of the country's critical infrastructure itself, this company is a significant actor in the sensitive energy sector. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Yes" response.

Economy.evidence: The official website of the Silk Road Chamber of International Commerce mentions two Lithuanian members: the Lithuanian Confederation of Industrialists and the Association of Lithuanian Chambers of Commerce, Industry, and Crafts. Lithuanian data confirms this. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Yes" response.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Economy.evidence: China has been using economic statecraft and coercion against Lithuania on an increasingly regular basis, with the recent (2021-2022) full-scale economic pressure campaign being among the most notorious and peculiar examples worldwide. Not only did it target sectors particularly dependent on the Chinese market, such as the laser industry, but its unannounced and unofficial so-called secondary sanctions aimed at Lithuanian-made components in global supply chains, eventually triggering an EU-wide response. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Yes" response.

Society.evidence: Although there is no explicit mention of words like "Promotion of Peaceful Reunification" in its title, the Overseas Chinese Association of Lithuania has been functioning in the country since 2016. Its official website hints at regular contacts with "Peaceful Reunification" organizations in other European countries and has published a "joint declaration" on this topic. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Few" and "Significant" rating.

Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Yes" response.
